intro: Crepis chrysantha subsp. chrysantha, commonly known as the golden hairgrass, is a flowering plant belonging to the family Asteraceae. It is characterized by its slender, grass-like stems and small, yellowish flowers that bloom in late summer. The plant typically grows in dry, open habitats such as meadows and rocky soils. It has narrow, linear leaves and produces small, wind-dispersed seeds. This subspecies is notable for its ornamental value and is sometimes cultivated in gardens.
